Prometheus.

PROGRAMME.
2.-THE DESERT BY SUNSET.
Features of the Desert -Means of Transit—Mohammed Ali and the Mernlooks.

3.THE MIDDLE STATION.
Discomfort of the Journey— My Companions—The Overland Babies -Song, " The Camel Bide."

4-A STREET IN CAIRO.
The Arabian Nights' Entertainments realized—Shepherd's Hotel, and its English peculiarities—Undecided
Mr- Parker, his Duet with the Cornet and Piano—The Coffee-house in the public Square Arab Music.

5.-THE KANDJIA, OR NILE BOAT.
6.-THE PYRAMIDS.

Its discomforts, opposed to general descriptions of Eastern Travellers-~Song, " The Boat on the -file.''
The Ascent, and English Luncheon on the Summit The Guides and their Antiquities—A bargainforsome Deities,
Who can the Arabs' Liberal Old Gentleman be !

7.THE LOCKS AT ATFEH,
(At the Junction of the Nile with the Mahmoodeeh Canal)
The Transit Steamer—An American Showman, and Importer of Panoramas and Curiosities

8.-THE SQUARE AT ALEXANDRIA.

(With the Raw Protestant Church)
Departure by the French Steamer "Osiris^—The Inglish Engineer, and hi* dilemma- The Sailor with his Tin Kidlc
Song, "L* Moulin du Vfflage..—The Polyglot Traveller: a Caution te Fl-trote-boA Sta.t*n..-Song, 'The Fast Mm,"

PORT

OF

SUEZ.

•Characteristics of Suez —Usual impatience of Travellers to get away.

Features of the Desert—Means of Transit—Mohtunmed AH and the Memlooks.

3.-THE

MIDDLE

STATION.

Discomfort of the Journey My Companions-The Overland Babies—Song, " The Camel Bide."

4.~A S T R E E T I N

CAIRO.

The Arabian Night.' Entertainments realized Shepherd's Hotel, and its English peculiarities—Undecided
Mr. Parker, his Duet with the Cornet and Piano—The Coffee-house in the public Square—Arab Music.

K A N D J I A , OR NILE

BOAT.

Its discomforts, oppo-ed to general descriptions of Eastern Travellers- -Song, " The Boat on the Nile."

PYRAMIDS.

ORPHEUSsPIPE PUT OUT BY THE BACCH2E.
Who tear him (as is reported) Into 20 pieces,

S W I M M I N G OF T H E H E A D DOWN T H E H E R R U S .
(A CLASSICAL COMPLAINT)
" Tet even in death Eurydice he sung
Eurydice the woods—
Eurydice still trembled on his tongue;
Eurydice the floods;
Eurydice the rocks, and hollow mountains rung"—Pop*.
